figure_1.title: Figure 1.
figure_1.caption: Distribution of estimated latent change in AARC-Gains (upper left panel) and AARC-Losses (lower left panel) and change in the gains-to-losses ratio (right panel) across a two-year interval in very old age

figure_2.title: Figure 2.
figure_2.caption: Forest plot of estimated directional effects of health, cognitive function and engagement with life on perceived age-related losses (left panel, filled circles) and gains (right panel, filled circles). Estimates for these effects from a controlled model (i.e. that allows for potential reverse causation) are displayed as open circles in each second line.

claims.sentence: Figure 1 shows in its left-hand panel the distribution of estimated latent changes in AARC-Gains and AARC-Losses across both waves (i.e., slopes).

However, this gain-to-loss ratio was initially less favorable in older age groups, decreased with time in all age groups, and flipped to slightly more losses than gains experienced at wave 2 in the oldest age group (see right panel of Figure 1).

Predictors of AARC-Gains and AARC-Losses and Test of Bidirectionality
Results from the SEM-based semi-cross-lagged panel fixed effects analysis are shown in Figure 2 as lines using the filled circle symbol.

Estimates for these effects from a controlled model (i.e. that allows for potential reverse causation) are displayed as open circles in each second line.When taking the possibility of reverse causation into account (see lines using the open circle symbol in Figure 2), only the estimated effect of changes in IADL remained significant.
With respect to perceived AARC-Gains (Figure 2, right panel, filled circles), the fixed effects model suggested a directional effect of intra-individual changes in leisure-time activity on gains.
Figure 1 shows in its left-hand panel the distribution of estimated latent changes in AARC-Gains and AARC-Losses across both waves (i.e., slopes).

However, this gain-to-loss ratio was initially less favorable in older age groups, decreased with time in all age groups, and flipped to slightly more losses than gains experienced at wave 2 in the oldest age group (see right panel of Figure 1).

However, this gain-to-loss ratio was initially less favorable in older age groups, decreased with time in all age groups, and flipped to slightly more losses than gains experienced at wave 2 in the oldest age group (see right panel of Figure 1).

Results from the SEM-based semi-cross-lagged panel fixed effects analysis are shown in Figure 2 as lines using the filled circle symbol.

With respect to perceived AARC-Gains (Figure 2, right panel, filled circles), the fixed effects model suggested a directional effect of intra-individual changes in leisure-time activity on gains.
